title: 104_hr1079
content: The Act is titled the "Smithsonian Institution Sesquicentennial Commemorative Coin Act" and specifies the coin specifications. The "Smithsonian Institution Sesquicentennial Commemorative Coin Act" authorizes the minting of $5 gold coins and $1 silver coins with specific weights, diameters, and compositions. These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items under the Act. According to the "Smithsonian Institution Sesquicentennial Commemorative Coin Act," all coins minted under this Act are considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain gold for minting coins from existing authorities and silver only from stockpiles established under a specific Act. The design of the coins will be determined under this Act. The design of coins minted under this Act must symbolize the significance of the Smithsonian Institution and include specific inscriptions. The design will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The design of coins minted under this Act shall be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Smithsonian Institution and the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single mint facility during a specific period from August 10, 1996, to August 9, 1997. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. Surcharges will be included in all sales. The $5 coin will be sold at $35 per coin, and the $1 coin will be sold at $10 per coin. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to the Smithsonian for 150th-anniversary programs. 15% supports the National Numismatic Collection. The Comptroller General can audit the Smithsonian's expenditures. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure no net cost to the government for minting and issuing coins. Payment for coins requires full payment, security, or a guarantee from a depository institution.
